author: jgm
content:
We've always been away that a majority consensus failure would leave us in a bad place.  We've generally ignored that up until now, because we've focused on client diversity to show that it isn't an issue.  And, to be realistic, this was an incredibly unlucky circumstance both in terms of the client distribution on the chain and the likelihood of the bug not beig picked up on three independent clients.  But it did happen, so I think that we need to be able to show that we can handle this situation (even if only theoretically).

Moving ahead with the next upgrades without being able to address this situation isn't a good look, in my opinion, as we would be building on a foundation of sand.

author: parithosh
content:
Q: Would any client allow me to basically take the last finalized state (pre-fork). Use a fixed EL. It should sync up, realize there are no valid slots from finalized to head - and go into a mode where it builds on top of itself and leaks all other validators? 

The building on top of itself is the important bit (i.e, a node needs to go out of SYNCING and into just non-finalizing and building when its my turn), because then i can statically peer other nodes I have onto this chain - including a bunch of extra nodes allowing others to sync to it without rate limiting.

The mainnet analog ofc is us basically choosing a canonical chain socially and finding a way to sync to it.

author: arnetheduck
content: https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/blob/dev/specs/phase0/fork-choice.md#fork-choice - the `anchor_block`/`anchor_state` determines the finalized checkpoint in fork choice - there is no requirement that this is the same as the finalized checkpoint field in the anchor state

author: arnetheduck
content: tbh, I don't know what that will do for slashings etc, that's worthy of investigation, but starting from a checkpoint _makes_ that state finalized in fork choice
